resources.string: The roll of 1 and 2 (acey-deucey) is especially valuable. When you roll 1-2, you name any roll of doubles you wish and play it accordingly.
After taking your 4 moves with doubles, the player rolls again.
A checker sitting alone on a point is called a blot. If an opposing checker lands on a blot, the blot is hit and placed on pokey.

Any time you have one or more checkers on pokey, you have to reenter them on the board before moving any other pieces. You reenter a checker by rolling doubles and moving it to an open point corresponding to one of the numbers on the rolled dice.

Once you have moved all fifteen of your checkers into your opponent\'s home board, you may begin bearing off. You bear off a checker by rolling a number that corresponds to the point on which it resides, then removing the checker from the board.
The loser drinks one for each of his checkers still on the board (or yet to be entered). Gammons and backgammons do not count extra.
